content: I've just fixed the typo "explaination" (should be "explanation") in Goal section.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Well done! Liked it.

In the hope it encourages someone to try to create a puzzle also, there is the little story behind this puzzleðŸ˜…

I wanted to create my first contribution on Codingame and having played many COC involving collatz conjecture, i knew that conjectures can be a good area to start as some are very simple to understand, code and verify. 

So i went online looking for one like that and after few hours of reading about conjectures i found this one. Then i decided to code and test it by myself. i wrote a pretty simple code. Then i decided to use it to make a puzzle. 

I ended up creating 2 puzzles in the same topic, one COC and this classic puzzle. The COC didn't even used a sieve. (i didn't know about the sieve of sudaram (and all the others, excepted Eratosthenes because of school) before starting to work on this puzzle. )

But for the classic puzzle i decided to make it more challeging to pretend to medium, so i searched for a faster way to do find primes numbers up to n than just checking each number up to sqrt(n) and i found the sieve of sudaram than i used here, but the code i found on geekforgeeks was slow in lookups so i improved it a little bit and here we are. 

So if you're thinking of creating a puzzle and you're a little bit afraid, just start and know that the community is here to help you.

Have you verified that this challenge is solvable in many languages?

Consider stating that this challenge is about optimazation.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment:

Really nice puzzle. I tried to do it without reading your solution. I was able to pass to Dalmatians doing a compromise on m, but I was never able to pass Tacites. It was quite frustrating because I optimized my solution with memoization and a quite optimized prime computation (less than 30% numbers are tested).

Reading your solution: 
- the sieve sundaram algo is interesting. I didn't know about it. Your explanation should definitly talk about it as I really feel like it is not possible to solve the puzzle without it (at least with m up to 1000000)
- the OOS in your solution is a good idea but again, your explanation should talk about expected output in case of unexpected input

Please remove the extra "the" in the "n next lines" part of your Input.  I believe it should be:

an even integer m, the number for which all the couples of prime factors must be found, counted and printed.

Secondly, should the word "factors" be replaced with "addends" or just "numbers"?
a
Very interesting !
Very interesting to understand how searching in a non-indexed set can affect performance
Good one, the optimization at the end stumped me for a bit, not sure I would have been able to do it in less than 15 minutes ahah
nice one
Nice puzzle with performance optimization at the end

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is a nice and easy puzzle featuring great mathematical conjecture
There is no m = 10^6 in the tests, where it definitely should be. Also, it is nice to put an odd number in the sample, so players would see "OOS" case. Apart from that, I like the puzzle.
Please distinguish the cases of "out of scope" (because the number is odd) and "impossible" (because the number is even but no possible sum can be found). Please don't mix them. Thanks.
Since Goldbach's conjecture is about even numbers, what for you attach odd numbers in tests?

Cases
* m is 0 in "Be careful" validator. It is inconsistent with the second constraint, which states that m > 0. Please fix either the case or the constraint.

* Two cases contain duplicated numbers, not sure if that is intentional and if that is a good idea or not?
â€¢ In "Dalmatians" test, both 876 and 1953 appear twice.
â€¢ In "Dalmatians" validator, both 3063 and 8148 appear twice.

Thanks.

Thank you very much for your feedback.

The duplication were because i my script to generate big test cases i did not implement somthing to prevent duplicates. I've removed them.

You're right. I've fixed it all. 

Is it better now ?

Hi
It's a good question. 
It's just to increase the complexity of the puzzle a little bit.
The last test which is focused on performance doesn't have odd numbers.

Assuming the conjecture is true, it implies that for any given "in scope" number, it's always possible to find two prime numbers summing to it. So i don't have 'impossible' cases.

Does this updated description fix the issue ? If yes, i'll update the puzzle

Goldbach's conjecture is one of the oldest and best-known unsolved problems in number theory and all of mathematics. It states that every even natural number greater than 2 is the sum of two prime numbers.

For each given integer [[m]], find when in scope (all premises for the conjecture are true) , all distinct prime couples summing to [[m]], and print their count.

When the given number is out of scope, print {{OOS}} (for OUT OF SCOPE).

<<Example explanation:>> 38 get these 2 possible sums
38 = 7 + 31
38 = 19 + 19

Thanks for the feedback.
I've added the case for 10^6.
But for the sample about OOS, it think it will make it those cases too obvious and therefore useless like Konstant was suggesting. I'm still thinking about removing them alltoghether from the problem...

Thanks.
But this is a classic puzzle, not a COC, so you can take your timeðŸ˜…

One more thing.  The phrase "38 get these 2 possible sums" seems odd.  Shouldn't it be, "38 gets..."?

or maybe something like:

Example explanation: the following 2 combinations of prime numbers sum to 38

I have completed the puzzle.  Other than these very minor issues, I believe this is a solid puzzle and it is ready to go.

Hi C6PO. Thanks for your feedback.
- in fact they are many sieves that can work here (Sundaram, Eratosthenes, Atkin...) as long as the time complexity is better than N^2. So even for those seed we must look for an optimized version of them. By exemple the code for the sieve of sudaram i'm using in my solution comes from the website geekforgeeks, but i have to optimize it a little bit by changing the dprimes dictionnary to improve the lookup time for it to work...
- I've decided to remove the OOS aspect from the puzzle completly following the suggestions of other community members, i've just omited to remove it from my solution as it still works , and the solution is not meant to be seing buy players... But yeah, i'll probably do that too

Ps: i didn't know about the sieve of sudaram (and all the others, excepted Eratosthenes because of school) before starting to work on this puzzle.  I wanted to create my first contribution on Codingame and having played many COC involving collatz conjecture, i knew that conjectures can be a good area to start as some are very simple to understand, code and verify. So i went online looking for one like that and after few hours of reading about conjectures i found this one. Then i decided to code and test it by myself. i wrote a pretty simple code. Then i decided to use it to make a puzzle. I ended up creating 2 puzzles in the same topic, one COC and this classic puzzle. The COC didn't even used a sieve. But for the classic puzzle i decided to make it more challeging to pretend to medium, so i searched for a faster way to do find primes numbers up to n than just checking each number up to sqrt(n) and i found the sieve of sudaram than i used here, but the code i found on geekforgeeks was slow in lookups so i improved it a little bit and here we are.

Hi OddBitKid.
That's a good point.

Truly speaking no. 
My thought process was "if it can be solved in JavaScript" it can proably be solved in any language".

For sure i can be solved in all compiled languages. And this solution in Js shows that i probably can be solve in most interpreted languages too, so... 

Do you know a language in which it might not be possible ?
Maybe, this comment was better suited as a blog than as a 'comment to self'.
Yeah. you're right. I'll try to find time to do that.

Hi Timinator. Thanks for your feedback.
My english is a little bit brokenðŸ˜….
Starting from the bottom:

I'll adopt this wording : " the following 2 combinations of prime numbers sum to 38"

Yes "numbers" can be used instead of "factors" but it seemed to me that 'factors' is a common term in this area like in "Prime Factors Decomposition"... But i don't mind changing it if it make the puzzle more understandable... Should i ?

Idk, maybe someone with editing rights allready fixed it, but i don't see the extra "the" you're talking about. The sentence is the exact one you are suggesting.

The extra "the" is still there.  Here is the sentence:

an even integer m, the number for which the all the couples of prime factors must be found, counted and printed.

"the all the" should be "all the"

As for readability or understandability, I don't think anybody will ever have an issue with the word "factor".  Technically though, a factor is a number that divides another number, leaving no remainder.  This puzzle does not have any division or multiplication in it, so factors do not come into play.  Prime Factor Decomposition would indeed involve multiplication and division so the use of the word factors works there.  You can leave it as is or change it to be technically correct. This puzzle will be successful either way.
Thank you very much. you're right. i've update it.
Oh right, my bad! Well It seems perfect for a puzzle, I learnt some things solving it :)
Awesome. I'm glad to know that.

I would suggest to change the sentence to "If the given number is odd, or it is not greater than 2, it is out of scope (OOS). In that case, print {{OOS}}".

Thanks.

I was thinking the player should deduce this after a careful reading of the problem statement. So i didn't want to explicitly state it, to not make it too obvious, otherwise it just become like adding noise to the input as Konstant was saying. What do you think ?
I agree with your other idea (in the comment to nikgaevoy) and Konstant's suggestion to just remove those cases altogether :)

Hello @5DN1L,
I've remove the OOS aspect
If so, then please check testcases, because 1501 is a sum of primes 1499 and 2. Also rephraze statement that you ask for check also odd numbers

Yes you're right. I should be more precise. Thanks for making me realize that. 

What about this?

For each given integer m, find when possible (all premises for the conjecture are true) , all distinct prime couples summing to m, and print their count.

Does it make it more clear?

My intention is to make understand that, if the number is not even (premise 1) or less than 3 (premise 2), we're not in a Goldbach's conjecture situation (premises are not all true), so we should not even try to compute something and just say it's impossible.

If it's more clear it will solve the issue you pointed out with odd numbers like 1501.

IMO puzzle should focus about Goldbachâ€™s Conjecture, so do not need  add noise in input. 
You want player to exclude odd numbers which is one line of code, it doesn't make puzzle more complex
Or maybe at least change "IMPOSSIBLE" to "OUT OF SCOPE" for the odd number cases.

Hello Guys.
Thanks again for your feedback, it's very helping. This is my first contribution for classic puzzle, so I've a lot to learn about how to make it good.

I've try to take into consideration both your suggestions, except Konstant's last one.

Is it better now?
Hello @Konstant, i've followed your idea finally
Yes, it's better now, thank you :)
